div.p: Short for emphasis, EMPH signifies emphasis placed by writer of entry (use very sparingly) or which is part of source quoted. In the latter case it may represent italic or bold or small caps in source. It is available throughout the textbase from the Div1 level down everywhere that typing is allowed (HEADINGs, CHRONPROSE, SHORTPROSE), and surrounds only those words that should be set apart typographically from surrounding text. When transcribing QUOTEs from texts (mostly early ones) which over-use emphatic typography, you may choose not to reproduce it (with a SCHOLARNOTE to that effect). This tag has no required sub-elements or unique attributes.

div.codeblock: Eliza Fenwick, who had recently decided <EMPH>not</EMPH> to join her daughter in Barbados, embarked with her son on the two-month voyage there. In the following example emphasis is marked as coming from the original source, a letter from Mary Taylor to Charlotte BrontÃ«: <QUOTE>You talk of women working. And this first duty, this necessity you seem to think that <EMPH>some</EMPH> women may indulge in -- if they give up marriage and don't make themselves too disagreeable to the other sex. You are a coward and a traitor. A woman who works is by that alone better than one who does not.</QUOTE>

div.p: EMPH will likely be used very rarely in project documents. Designed for the TEI, emph is best used by projects recording pre-existing texts where words have been emphasized by typography but the encoder has no indication of why the words have been set off. If you are considering using the emph element, please consult the glossary for the FOREIGN, Rs, SOCALLED, and TITLE elements to ensure that your purposes are not better served by one of these elements.
